content:
ASIA

US President Trump said US worth has increased by USD 10tln since the election and that China’s economy is down lately. Furthermore, Trump commented that not enough focus is being placed on China and that tariffs on tech from China is leading to economic gain. (Newswires)


UK

UK Brexit Minister Raab said he is confident a good Brexit deal is within sight and that getting a good deal is by far the most likely outcome, while Raab also stated he will not allow anything to create a hard border in Ireland even in a no-deal scenario. (Newswires)

Austria's Chancellor Kurz said he wants to help EU's Barnier to avoid a hard Brexit. (Newswires)

EU

ECB Minutes stated that threat of protectionism and prominent trade tensions could weigh on confidence, while it also noted that policymakers are unanimous in maintaining policy stance and are satisfied that the June decisions are well understood. Furthermore, ECB noted that uncertainties around inflation are receding, that expectations remain that H1 slowdown was temporary and that the winding down of asset purchases will be subject to incoming data. (Newswires)

Italy’s Deputy PM and Five-Star leader Di Maio stated his party will vote to suspend EU funding next year if on Friday European Commission does not get a deal for other states to take in some of migrants on an Italian coastguard ship. (Newswires)

EU Markit Services Flash PMI (Aug) 54.4 vs. Exp. 54.4 (Prev. 54.2)
EU Markit Comp Flash PMI (Aug) 54.4 vs. Exp. 54.5 (Prev. 54.3)


FX

Russian Central Bank stated they have enough tools to prevent threats to financial stability and announced not to purchase foreign currency from now until end of September to curb FX volatility, while the decision on renewal of forex buying will be taken on the basis of the situation in September. There were also comments from Russia’s Finance Ministry that the central bank’s decision to pause FX buying will not affect the ministry’s planned FX purchases for the budget. (Newswires)
 

COMMODITIES

North Sea Oil strikes are reportedly to continue as talks with Total have broken down. (Newswires)
 

US

Fed's Bostic (Voter, Dove) said the FOMC has spent some time discussing the yield curve and that outlook is for above trend expansion in the coming quarters, while he also noted trade uncertainty as the chief downside risk. (Newswires)

Fed's Kaplan (Non-Voter, Dove) said the job of the Fed is to make decisions independent of politics and that impact of trade dispute on the US economy is so far modest but could affect business sentiment. Furthermore, Kaplan sees 3-4 hikes in the next 9-12 months and stated he hopes Fed can get to the neutral rate without seeing a yield curve inversion. (Newswires)

Mexico Economy Minister Guajardo said Mexican NAFTA negotiators are prepared to stay in Washington over the weekend if needed and later added they will have to work on NAFTA into next week. In related news, there were comments from Canadian Foreign Minister Freeland that Canada would need to 'agree to any final conclusion' achieved on rules of origin in NAFTA talks between the US and Mexico. (Newswires)

US President Trump sought advice on the possibility of a Manafort pardon, although Trump lawyer Giuliani advised him against pardoning Manafort. (Washington Post/Newswires)

US Markit Manufacturing PMI Flash (Aug) 54.5 vs. Exp. 55 (Prev. 55.3). (Newswires)
US Markit Services PMI Flash (Aug) 55.2 vs. Exp. 55.9 (Prev. 56)
US Markit Comp Flash PMI Aug 55.0 (Prev. 55.7)
 

MARKET RECAP

US equity futures grinded higher for the first half of the session and were further boosted at the US cash open. However, gains were short lived as gains were completely erased following Yuan weakness as well as some traders citing unconfirmed reports that Special Counsel Mueller plans to claim that Trump Jr lied to the FBI over the Trump Tower meeting (note, this is an unconfirmed rumour), while some also suggested weakness in BABA shares was a contributing factor. In terms of individual stocks, AMD (AMD) was higher after Rosenblatt raised the co.’s price target to a street high of $30 from $27. Walmart (WMT) was slightly lower after a UK competition watchdog started its formal investigation into the planned $7.3bln merger between the co.’s supermarket chain ASDA, and Sainsbury (SBRY LN). L Brands (LB) was under pressure on Thursday following poor earnings. LB slightly beat on both top & bottom lines, however, the co. lowered FY18 and Q3 EPS forecasts. Synopsys (SNPS) outperformed after both EPS & revenue were higher than expectations. Alibaba (BABA) was indecisive after its EPS beat but revenues fell, with the stock initially opening higher but giving up its gains as investors focused on the operating margin which fell 10% Q/Q and 35% y/y due to Ant Financial expenses, as well as the investment BABA is making in new areas. SPX -0.2% at 2857, NDX -0.1% at 7414, DJI -0.3% at 25657.

The US Treasury sold $14bln of 5-year TIPS, which sold at the highest yield since 2009, stopping through by 0.1bps. In the week of 27 August, the US Treasury plans to issue $36bln of new 2-year notes on Monday, $37bln of new 5-year notes on Tuesday, and new $31bln of new 7-year notes on Wednesday, for total of $104bln. On Thursday, the curve was mixed, though once again, there were new cyclical flats for the 2s5s and 2s10s, as has become almost customary on a daily basis. US 10-Year T-notes settled 1 tick lower at 120-19.

US Market Wrap - US MARKET WRAP - 23 Aug 2018: Risk-off amid trade uncertainty, as US-China talks resume
content:
To download the report, please click here. If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

* SNAP-SHOT: Equities mixed, Treasuries flat, crude flat, dollar up.
* REAR-VIEW: Jackson Hole kicks-off; ECB Minutes warns on protectionism; China files WTO complaint over US; Fed speak.
* AHEAD: Fed's Chair Powell at Jackson Hole; Japan CPI; Germany GDP; US Durable Goods, Baker Hughes rig count, Aussie politics. 

* CHINA TRADE TALKS: China’s Commerce Ministry said it has filed a complaint at the WTO regarding US tariffs, after the US’ latest 25% levies on an additional USD 16bln of Chinese goods, which came into effect on Thursday. China’s Foreign Ministry said it was hopeful that a good result will come out of the low-level US in trade talks, adding that it was hopeful of the US meeting it halfway. Separately, the Commerce Ministry said it was regretful that the decision made by Australia to ban Huawei and ZTE from the country’s 5G network, due to national security concerns, noting it will have a negative effect on bilateral business interests. US President Trump noted China’s economy is down lately and emphasized that not enough focus is being placed on the region, adding that tariffs on tech is leading to economic gains. He also announced the US worth has increased by 10 trillion dollars since the election.

* NAFTA: Mexico’s Economy Minister Guajardo said that August is the official timeline to try and get a deal done on NAFTA; he added they are doing their best to finish talks as soon as possible but noted that there are always sticking points in negotiations. Canada’s Foreign Minister Freeland also reiterated similar comments from last night noting US & Mexican progress on bilateral talks ‘is an essential, encouraging step’ towards a new deal and specified Canada would need to 'agree to any final conclusion' achieved on rules of origin in NAFTA talks between the US and Mexico.

* FED: Fed's George (Hawk) said she favours two more rate hikes this year; adding that a 2.5%-3.0% neutral rate is reasonable estimate. She sees 3% GDP growth in 2018 and thinks the yield curve is a factor in the Fed's policy. She also noted US President Trump's commentary is not altering her vote decision making. Fed's Kaplan (Non-Voter, Dovish) said the job of the Fed is to make decisions independent of politics in response to the comments made by US President Trump on the Fed. He sees a modest impact of trade dispute on the US economy, but it could affect business sentiment. He went on to say the Fed expects to tail off as the impact of fiscal stimulus recedes and he expressed hope that the Fed can get to the neutral rate without seeing a yield curve inversion. Finally, he sees 3-4 hikes in the next 9-12 months. Fed's Bostic (Voter, Dove) said his outlook is for above trend expansion in the coming quarters and sees trade uncertainty as the chief downside risk. He also stated the FOMC has spent some time discussing the yield curve.

* BREXIT: UK Brexit Minister Raab sees risks and challenges in a no-deal scenario but also opportunities and reported to be making good progress on outstanding separation issue. He added the EU is still probing the UK proposals over the Irish border issues, though he will not allow anything to create a hard border in Ireland, even in a no-deal scenario. Nonetheless he appeared confident that a good Brexit deal is within sight, stressing that getting a good deal is by far the most likely outcome. UK Chancellor Hammond also commenting on a ‘no-deal’ Brexit, said 'GDP impacts of this magnitude, were they to arise, would have large fiscal consequences’ for the UK. Finally, Austria's Chancellor Kurz says he wants to help EU's Barnier to avoid a hard Brexit

* ECB MINUTES: The minutes of the central bank's latest meeting provided few surprises. The central bank said that the threat of protectionism and prominent trade tensions could weigh on confidence in the Euro-area, but sounded upbeat on the economy, arguing that expectations remain that the H1 2018 slowdown was temporary, growth was broad-based and solid, and in-line with the June projections; on price pressures, it said that uncertainties around inflation were receding. Policymakers were unanimous in maintaining policy stance and were satisfied that the June decisions are well-understood by markets. Finally, it said that winding down of its asset purchases will be subject to incoming data.

* ECB: ECB's Weidmann (Hawkish) believes it is time to end expansionary monetary policy and emphasized ending QE is just the first step. He said normalization will be gradual and will take a few years, urging to avoid delays. He suggested a trade war could be "severely detrimental" to the global economy. On the German economy he said it is flourishing, with the upswing likely to continue, even though the expansionary pace is unlikely to be kept and sees uncertainty on the rise.

* GEOPOLITICS:  In response to sanctions, the Russian Deputy Foreign Minister said Russia will not halt exports of titanium to the US for its aviation industry.

 * NEW HOME SALES added to the recent disappointing housing data, falling 1.7% in July (expectations were for a 2.2% rise). This time the drop was attributed to the stormy weather which has impacted regions in the Northeast and South and depressed US sales over summer. In terms of trend, sales have now been falling for three times in the last four months and are clearly edging lower with weaker foreign demand cited as a possible motive, Wells Fargo said. However, Wells Fargo does not think demand all-together has weakened, since the median home price moved higher in July. 

* ITALY: 5-Star Leader Di Maio said his party would be willing to suspend EU funding next year if on Friday the European Commission does not get a deal to divvy up migrants on a ship; Italian politicians have been calling for the Europe to share the responsibility for migrants entering the EU via Italy.

* FUTURES: US equity futures grinded higher for the first half of the session and were further boosted at the US cash open. However, gains were short lived as gains were completely erased following Yuan weakness as well as some traders citing unconfirmed reports that Special Counsel Mueller plans to claim that Trump Jr lied to the FBI over the Trump Tower meeting (note, this is an unconfirmed rumour), while some also suggested weakness in BABA shares was a contributing factor.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: AMD (AMD) was higher after Rosenblatt raised the co.’s price target to a street high of $30 from $27. Walmart (WMT) was slightly lower after a UK competition watchdog started its formal investigation into the planned $7.3bln merger between the co.’s supermarket chain ASDA, and Sainsbury (SBRY LN). L Brands (LB) was under pressure on Thursday following poor earnings. LB slightly beat on both top & bottom lines, however, the co. lowered FY18 and Q3 EPS forecasts. Synopsys (SNPS) outperformed after both EPS & revenue were higher than expectations. Alibaba (BABA) was indecisive after its EPS beat but revenues fell, with the stock initially opening higher but giving up its gains as investors focused on the operating margin which fell 10% Q/Q and 35% y/y due to Ant Financial expenses, as well as the investment BABA is making in new areas.  

* WTI (V8) SETTLES 3 CENTS LOWER AT $67.83/BBL; BRENT (V8) SETTLES 5 CENTS LOWER AT $74.73/BBL. Saudi Arabia’s energy minister denied reports that the Aramco IPO has been cancelled, and said it remains committed to Aramco IPO, and is looking for the right market conditions for the IPO. Nigeria’s crude exports to Asia tose to a 2-year high in July to 664k BPD, due to shrinking Brent/Dubai EFS, PVM reported.

* US 10-YEAR T-NOTES SETTLED 1 TICK LOWER AT 120-19: The US Treasury sold $14bln of 5-year TIPS, which sold at the highest yield since 2009, stopping through by 0.1bps. In the week of 27 August, the US Treasury plans to issue $36bln of new 2-year notes on Monday, $37bln of new 5-year notes on Tuesday, and new $31bln of new 7-year notes on Wednesday, for total of $104bln. On Thursday, the curve was mixed, though once again, there were new cyclical flats for the 2s5s and 2s10s, as has become almost customary on a daily basis.

* EMFX: Some much needed respite for the Rouble and a degree of positive contagion across the region after the CBR halted foreign currency purchases until the end of next month with the aim of curbing FX market volatility and declared it has enough in its locker to maintain financial stability. USD/RUB pulled back sharply from around 69.0000 to sub-67.5000 at best, with further impetus coming via reports suggesting that US President Trump may not have been aware of a meeting with Russian officials, according to his ex-lawyer Cohen. As noted, partial relief elsewhere, but the Real, Rand, Lira and Peso still suffering net losses vs a firmer Dollar overall post-FOMC minutes underscoring at least one more hike this year, in September.

* AUD: No such luck for the AUD that lost more ground vs the USD and NZD, through 0.7275 and towards 1.0900 respectively as ongoing political instability/uncertainty (after high profile Government resignations and more challenges to PM Turnbull) was exacerbated by Aussie-China tensions over 5G. AUD/USD bears now eyeing last Friday/week lows around 0.7250/0.7200, while the Kiwi is testing 0.6650 support/bids vs its US counterpart.

* JPY, GBP, CAD: The next worst G10 performers vs the Greenback, as the DXY rebounded to 95.500+ again after another downturn, with USD/JPY clearing decent option expiries just ahead of 111.00 and the 55 DMA to take out some layered offers above the big figure on the way to 111.25. Meanwhile, Cable lost further ground from 1.2900+ to under 1.2850 and EUR/GBP retested 0.9000+ after little net reaction to a strong CBI retail survey and no deal guidelines from Brexit Minister Raab. The Loonie retreated from sub-1.3000 vs its US peer towards lows close to 1.3080 as NAFTA deal prospects before the end of the month at the earliest appear more realistic than this week or even sooner.

* EUR, CHF: Relative outperformers, or rather more resilient vs the broad USD revival, as the single currency held above 1.1550 and Franc only extended its range to around 0.9855 from circa 0.9825 at the other end of Thursday’s EU trading parameters.

content: The US will tap the TII April 2023 for $14bln on Thursday. Analysts at Societe Generale say 5-year TIPS have been cheapening up in real yield terms since the first issue of this bond back in April, and on inflation breakeven terms, 5-year has recently under performed other parts of the curve and US CPI swaps. However, SocGen notes that the the real yield and breakeven cheapening of the past few months should be a positive for this auction, and therefore, the supply should be well-absorbed.

RANsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 23rd August 2018 - Earnings from BABA, LB, SNPS
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

23rd August 2018

Earnings

Alibaba (BABA) Q2 Adj. EPS USD 1.22 vs. Exp. USD 1.14, revenue USD 12.2bln vs. Exp. USD 12.42bln. Reports annual active customers reached 576mln. The co. signs an agreement with Chongqing Sokon to work on an electric car. (Newswires)

Children's Place (PLCE) Q2 Adj. EPS USD 0.70 vs. Exp. USD 0.59, revenue USD 0.448bln vs. Exp. USD 0.427bln. Comparable retail sales increased 13.2% in Q2. Raises FY18 Adj. EPS and revenue view. (Newswires)

Hormel Foods (HRL) Q3 EPS USD 0.39 vs. Exp. USD 0.39, revenue USD 2.40bln vs. Exp. USD 2.38bln. (Newswires)

L Brands (LB) Q2 Adj. EPS USD 0.36 vs. Exp. USD 0.34, revenue USD 2.98bln vs. Exp. USD 2.93bln. Q2 consolidated SSS for Stores and Direct up 3%. Sees Q3 EPS USD 0.00-0.05, consensus USD 0.16. Lowers FY18 EPS view to USD 2.45-2.70 from USD 2.70-- USD 3.00, consensus 2.77. (Newswires)

Lancaster Colony (LANC) Q4 EPS USD 1.18 vs. Exp. USD 1.09, revenue USD 0.308bln vs. Exp. USD 0.294bln. (Newswires)

Sanderson Farms (SAFM) Q3 EPS USD 0.50 may not compare to consensus USD 1.36, revenue USD 0.852bln vs. Exp. USD 0.873bln. (Newswires)

Synopsis (SNPS) Q2 EPS USD 0.95 vs. Exp. USD 0.92, revenue USD 0.779bln vs. Exp. USD 0.773bln. (Newswires)

Williams-Sonoma (WSM) Q2 Adj. EPS USD 0.77 vs. Exp. USD 0.68, revenue USD 1.275bln vs. Exp. USD 1.26bln. (Newswires)

DJIA

Apple (AAPL) – The tech giant has entered an agreement with Simply Mac for the repair of iPhone screens. (9to5mac)

Chevron Corp (CVX) – The South African competition watchdog has authorised Glencore’s (GLEN LN) USD 900mln bid for Chevron’s local & Botswana assets, this improves the co.’s chances of acquiring the assets over rival bidder, China’s state-owned Sinopec. (Newswires)

Goldman Sachs Group (GS) – The investment bank has opened its digital consumer savings platform, Marcus, to its own staff in Britain; this is before a public roll-out of the platform. (Newswires)

Intel (INTC) – The co.’s Mobileye unit which develops advanced driver assistance solutions is looking to cooperate with Taiwan firms for the development of a n autonomous driving technology. (DigiTimes)

JP Morgan (JPM) – The bank is expanding its Sapphire card to include checking accounts to attract millennial customers. The card was launched two years ago and attracted millennials because of its travel pluses. (Newswires)

Merck (MRK) -The healthcare group and Eisai (ESALY) announced the FDA has granted marketing authorisation for LENVIMA for the treatment of hepatocellular carcinoma. (Newswires)

Microsoft (MSFT) – The tech group will disclose "Xbox All Access" a service that bundles Xbox One consoles with Xbox Live and Xbox Game Pass for a monthly fee. (The Verge)

Pfizer Inc. (PFE) – The pharma giant and Astellas Pharma (ALPMY) have made amendments to two of their phase 3 trials evaluating the safety and efficacy of XTANDI in men with hormone-sensitive prostate cancer, speeding the process of the trials. (Newswires)

Walmart (WMT) – Britain’s competition watchdog has started its formal investigation into the planned USD 7.3bln merger between the co.’s supermarket chain ASDA and Sainsbury (SBRY LN). (Newswires)

S&P500

Bristol-Myers (BMY) – The FDA approved EGFR Mutation Test v2 necessary for the safety and effectiveness of corresponding therapeutic products. (Newswires)

Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) – The Chipotle Cultivate Foundation is sponsoring the Chipotle Aluminaries Project, an accelerator programme to help growth-stage ventures. (Newswires)

Conagra (CAG) – The waiting period for the previously announced acquisition of Pinnacle Foods (PF) by Conagra has expired. (Newswires)

Darden Restaurants (DRI) – The co.’s Cheddar’s Scratch Kitchen chain have reported the possibility of a compromise in the restaurants point-of-sale system. (Newswires)

Honeywell (HON) – The co. announced that Garrett Motion and Resideo Tech, both subsidiaries of the co., have publicly filed Form 10 registration statements with the US SEC. Also, the co. raises FY18 Adj. EPS view to USD 8.10-8.20 from USD 8.05-8.15. (Newswires)

International Game Technology (IGT) – The gaming co. has received licensing as a sports betting platform in West Virginia. (Newswires)

Lockheed Martin (LMT) – The defence group suggested that Japanese firms should be responsible for more than a half of the production of the next fighter jet to be launched in 2030. (Nikkei Asian Review)

LyondellBasell (LYB) – Developments on the co.’s largest ever capital investment, a USD 2.4bln propylene oxide and tertiary butyl alcohol (PO/TBA) plant in Houston, have been made. Startup of the plant is planned for 2021 and will produce 1bln pounds of PO and 2.2bln pounds of TBA annually. (Newswires)

MetLife (MET) – The co. names Kishore Ponnavolu as President of the Asia region. (Newswires)

Nordstrom (JWN) – The department store co.’s board of directors have authorised a share buyback of up to USD 1.5bln of its common stock. (Newswires)

Praxair Inc (PX) – The co. has won conditional antitrust approval in Brazil, alongside Linde (LIN GY), for their planned merger; Linde will have to sell its entire business in Brazil. They are yet to gain approval from US regulators, the co.’s biggest challenge. (Newswires)

Wells Fargo (WFC) – After reports the bank closed an account in Florida due to the account’s ties to medical marijuana, the bank replied by saying it has no political position on the matter and the reports were “completely false” and said the close was due to staying in-line with Federal law. (Newswires)

NASDAQ 100

Activision Blizzard (ATVI) – The Overwatch League and Twitter have signed a multi-year agreement to include highlights and livestream content to the platform. (Newswires)

Facebook (FB) – The social media is planning to remove its data-security app from Apple’s (AAPL) Appstore after the iPhone maker said the app violated its data handling policy. Separately, the social platform announced the suspension of more than 400 apps as part of a developer data probe. The co. is looking to improve internet connection in Tanzania with Express Wi-Fi. (WSJ/Newswires)

Netflix (NFLX) – The co.’s margin could rise after backing away from Apple (AAPL). Separately it was mentioned positively at Vertical Group. (Imperial)

Qualcomm (QCOM) – Taiwan Semiconductor is to begin the production of Qualcomm’s Snapdragon chips in Q4. Separately, subsidiary Qualcomm Technologies and Datang Telecom Group announced the first multi-chipset vendor interoperability which includes applications to improve automotive safety, automated driving, and traffic efficiency. (DigiTimes/Newswires)

Starbucks (SBUX) - COO Rosalind Brewer purchases 5k shares in the co. (Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

Bluebird Bio (BLUE) – The co. partners up with Gritstone Oncology to develop cancer cell therapies. (Newswires)

Dexcom (DXCM) – The co. has acquired TypeZero Technologies, their offerings included personalised diabetes management systems. (Newswires)

Enterprise (EPD) – The co. has entered an agreement with American Midstream to optimise Gulf Coast assets under which the latter may purchase 25% in Enterprise’s Pascagoula natural gas processing plant. (Newswires)

Pandora (P) – The co. announced that Pandora Premium listeners are now able to share music on Snapchat. (Newswires)

Wabco (WBC) – The co. enters a strategic agreement with Hino Trucks for the provision of driver assistance systems. (Newswires)

subject: Russia’s Finance Ministry says the central bank’s decision to pause FX buying will not affect the ministry’s planned FX purchases for the budget

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 23rd August 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • European equities are largely mixed and trading without direction amidst the fresh US-China tariff action
  • FOMC minutes have given the flagging Usd a fillip, along with indirect props from rival currencies that are succumbing to more selling pressure
  • Looking ahead, highlights include ECB Minutes, US flash PMIs, US New Home Sales, and US-China trade talks in Washington

ASIA

Asia-Pac stock markets traded subdued with the region cautious amid political turmoil in Australia and as the 2nd round of Trump tariffs on China took effect. ASX 200 (-0.3%) was negative as a mega-storm brewed on the political front with PM Turnbull’s future in office highly doubtful after 3 cabinet members resigned including Finance Minister Cormann who advised the PM, no longer has party support, although losses in the index have been stemmed as participants reacted to a slew of earnings and with miners underpinned by recent strength in commodities. Elsewhere, Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) remained afloat on the back of a weaker JPY, while Shanghai Comp. (+0.3%) and Hang Seng (-0.5%) were jittery as the 2nd round of US tariffs on China took effect today and after the PBoC refrained from liquidity operations again. Finally, 10yr JGBs were relatively unchanged with only minimal gains seen from the cautious risk tone in the region and with demand also subdued amid weaker results at the enhanced liquidity auction for longer-dated bonds.

US tariffs of 25% on additional USD 16bln of Chinese goods took effect. There were also comments from China Commerce Ministry that it resolutely opposes the latest US tariffs and will file a complaint to WTO, while Mofcom added it will continue to fight back against US. (Newswires)

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 40bln. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8367 (Prev. 6.8271)

GEOPOLITICAL

Turkish President Erdogan spokesman stated there is rule of law in Turkey and the case regarding Pastor Brunson is an ongoing legal issue, while the spokesman also stated Turkey has no intention of beginning an economic war but cannot stay silent. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

ECB's Weidmann (Hawkish) says it is time to end expansionary monetary policy, and ending QE is just the first step, while he added normalization will be gradual, to take a "few" years, and must avoid delay. In regards to trade, he said trade war could be "severely detrimental" to global economy. (Newswires)

Russian Central Bank says has enough tools to prevent threats to financial stability and has decided not to purchase foreign currency from now until end of September. (Newswires)

US

US President Trump’s former Lawyer Michael Cohen was said to have told lawmakers last year that he did not know whether US President Trump knew of the meeting with Russian officials in Trump Tower. (Axios)

EU/UK

UK Brexit Minister Raab says he is confident a good Brexit deal is within sight; getting a good deal is by far the most likely outcome, while adding there will be risks and challenges in no-deal scenario but also opportunities; making good progress on outstanding separation issue. (Sky News)

German Chancellor Merkel has reportedly set her sights on backing a German head for the European Commission rather than backing Weidmann for head of the post-Draghi ECB. (Handelsblatt)

EU Markit Services Flash PMI (Aug) 54.4 vs. Exp. 54.4 (Prev. 54.2)

EU Markit Manufacturing Flash PMI (Aug) 54.6 vs. Exp. 55.1 (Prev. 55.1)

EU Markit Composite Flash PMI (Aug) 54.4 vs. Exp. 54.5 (Prev. 54.3)

EQUITIES

European equities are largely mixed and trading without direction amidst the fresh US-China tariff action. The IT sector is mimicking the outperformance seen on Wall Street and is currently the leading sector.

Ryanair (+6.6%) is currently leading the gains in the Stoxx 600 (alongside Sunrise amid an upgrade in EBITDA guidance) as the co. reached an agreement with the Irish pilots union after 22 hours of deliberation. 

Individual equity losses in Europe are driven by the general weakness in the EM scope, which is weighing on companies with exposure to the affected countries, such as Deutsche Bank (-2.3%) and Raiffeisen Bank (-3.05%), while Continental (-2.7%) fails to recover from yesterday’s losses.

FX

DXY - FOMC minutes have given the flagging Usd a fillip, along with indirect props from rival currencies that are succumbing to more selling pressure due to specific/independent bearish factors. Thus, the index and Dollar overall have rebounded, with the former reclaiming 95.000+ status and almost up to 95.500 again.

AUD - No respite for the Aud that is back on the rack after a fleeting rebound to around 0.7350 vs its US counterpart and sub-0.7300 on the latest political machinations down under. Indeed, the Aud is also extending losses relative to the NZD, with the cross down towards 1.0900 even though the Kiwi is back below 0.6700 vs the Usd.

GBP/EUR/CAD - All falling foul of the latest Greenback revival, with Cable only just holding above 1.2850 and the single currency losing more ground after setting another recovery top above 1.1600, but respecting decent chart resistance between the big figure and 1.1650 again. Meanwhile, the Loonie has acknowledged less encouraging NAFTA vibes (in terms of likely deal timing not progress towards an agreement), like the Peso, with Usd/Cad bouncing ahead of its 100 DMA (1.2986) towards 1.3050.

JPY/CHF - Relative outperformance vs the Usd above 111.00 and 0.9850 respectively as EM peers continue to wilt, while the former is also resisting some technical levels and befitting from supportive flows with 110.95 representing the 55 DMA and offers layered from 111.00 onwards. Note also, decent option expiry interest from 110.95-111.00 (1.3 bn) is capping the pair, and the same could be weighing on Eur/Usd given 1.1 bn rolling off at 1.1600, plus 2.3 bn at the 1.1625 strike.

EM - The usual suspects are being flogged again, but with the Rub and Zar really seeing the brunt of investor angst on US sanctions – Rouble and Rand both around 1% or more weaker vs the Greenback, before the former got a reprieve from CBR’s attempt to curb FX volatility while Axios reported comments from Cohen last year, that he did not know of the meeting with Russian Officials. Zar was initially pressured on US scrutiny of South Africa’s farm and land seizures, which all contributed to the tailwinds overnight for the greenback, there were reports South Africa's Presidency will seek clarification from US Embassy on Trump's tweet regarding land reform policy. Elsewhere, Usd/Cnh firmer after reports of Chinese banks selling Yuan vs Dollars on a forward basis and an uptick in the Cny fix after some retracement of late from the PBoC.

FIXED INCOME

Bunds and Gilts have recovered from another bout of selling and fresh session lows, at 162.95 and 123.25 (-5 and -7 ticks vs +23 and +16 ticks at one stage), but trade remains choppy amidst the start of position rolls and fluid headlines on Brexit, EM FX etc. Meanwhile, US Treasuries have pared overnight gains within tight ranges post-Fed minutes and ahead of a busy Thursday agenda ahead (claims, PMIs, new home sales etc).

COMMODITIES

Commodities are pressured amid the recent dollar strength after the FOMC minutes cemented rate hike expectations. WTI and Brent Oct’ 18 futures trade lower by 0.2% and 0.4% respectively after the US benchmark rose over 3% yesterday. News flow has been light for the complex thus far, however, it is worth noting the ongoing trade disputes may potentially dampen global demand. Meanwhile, sources initially reported the Saudi Aramco IPO listing has been halted, but Saudi Energy Minister later denied these reports. Elsewhere, precious and base metals also feel the effect of the aforementioned dollar strength with gold below USD 1190/oz.

Meanwhile, the Loonie has acknowledged less encouraging NAFTA vibes (in terms of likely deal timing not progress towards an agreement), like the Peso, with Usd/Cad bouncing ahead of its 100 DMA (1.2986) towards 1.3050.

JPY/CHF

Relative outperformance vs the Usd above 111.00 and 0.9850 respectively as EM peers continue to wilt, while the former is also resisting some technical levels and befitting from supportive flows with 110.95 representing the 55 DMA and offers layered from 111.00 onwards. Note also, decent option expiry interest from 110.95-111.00 (1.3 bn) is capping the pair, and the same could be weighing on Eur/Usd given 1.1 bn rolling off at 1.1600, plus 2.3 bn at the 1.1625 strike.

EM

The usual suspects are being flogged again, but with the Rub and Zar really seeing the brunt of investor angst on US sanctions – Rouble and Rand both around 1% or more weaker vs the Greenback. Elsewhere, Usd/Cnh firmer after reports of Chinese banks selling Yuan vs Dollars on a forward basis and an uptick in the Cny fix after some retracement of late from the PBoC.

PRIMER: ECB July Minutes due to be released Thursday 23rd August at 1230BST/0630CDT
content: This week’s ECB minutes release is set to offer very little in the way of fireworks given the lack of action at the July meeting. To recap last month’s proceedings, the Bank reiterated their view that they expect key rates to remain at present levels at least through the Summer of 2019, and as long as necessary to ensure continued sustained convergence of inflation. During the accompanying press conference, Draghi gave little away and batted away any questions trying to get him to pin down an exact timeframe for the next rate move by the ECB. Furthermore, Draghi stated that uncertainties relating to the trade environment remain prominent, but the Euro area economy is solid and broad-based. Rhetoric from the Bank since the July meeting has been particularly light with central bankers opting to take a break from the minutiae of EZ monetary policy. As such, anyone looking for a trading opportunity out of this week’s minutes release might be left disappointed with the account unlikely to offer any further insight into the Bank’s plans for further monetary tightening.

23rd August 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia-Pac stock markets traded subdued with the region cautious amid political turmoil in Australia and as the 2nd round of Trump tariffs on China took effect. ASX 200 (-0.3%) was negative as a mega-storm brewed on the political front with PM Turnbull’s future in office highly doubtful after 3 cabinet members resigned including Finance Minister Cormann who advised the PM, no longer has party support, although losses in the index have been stemmed as participants reacted to a slew of earnings and with miners underpinned by recent strength in commodities. (-0.3%) and Hang Seng (-0.8%) were jittery as the 2nd round of US tariffs on China took effect today and after the PBoC refrained from liquidity operations again. Finally, 10yr JGBs were relatively unchanged with only minimal gains seen from the cautious risk tone in the region and with demand also subdued amid weaker results at the enhanced liquidity auction for longer-dated bonds.

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 23rd August 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • FOMC minutes stated trade dispute poses downside risk to the US economy, adding it would soon be appropriate to raise rates
  • DXY whipsawed and briefly fell below 95.00 in a knee-jerk reaction to the trade-wary FOMC minutes
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Norwegian GDP, EZ and US flash PMIs, ECB Minutes, US New Home Sales, and US-China trade talks in Washington

FOMC MINUTES

FOMC minutes stated that escalation of trade disputes was potentially a consequential downside risk for the US economy, while the Fed pointed to ongoing trade disagreement and proposed trade measures as an important source of uncertainty and stated that any large-scale and prolonged trade dispute would likely have an adverse impact on business sentiment, investment and employment.

The minutes added that many participants said it would soon likely be appropriate to raise rates and that participants expect it will soon be appropriate to no longer refer to monetary policy as 'accommodative' in the not too distant future, while participants also expect US GDP to slow in H2 2018 but will remain above potential.

The minutes were interpreted as slightly dovish in which the USD softened slightly and T-Notes increased by 2 ticks, although the moves were pared shortly after given that the minutes did little to suggest a change in the pace of the Fed’s tightening cycle and with attention on the Fed now shifts towards the Jackson Hole economic symposium, and specifically, will the Fed participants there (Powell, Rosengren) express similar warnings that could hint that the FOMC was mulling a slowing in its trajectory of rate hikes.
 

ASIA

Asia-Pac stock markets traded subdued with the region cautious amid political turmoil in Australia and as the 2nd round of Trump tariffs on China took effect. ASX 200 (-0.3%) was negative as a mega-storm brewed on the political front with PM Turnbull’s future in office highly doubtful after 3 cabinet members resigned including Finance Minister Cormann who advised the PM, no longer has party support, although losses in the index have been stemmed as participants reacted to a slew of earnings and with miners underpinned by recent strength in commodities. Elsewhere, Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) remained afloat on the back of a weaker JPY, while Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) and Hang Seng (-0.8%) were jittery as the 2nd round of US tariffs on China took effect today and after the PBoC refrained from liquidity operations again. Finally, 10yr JGBs were relatively unchanged with only minimal gains seen from the cautious risk tone in the region and with demand also subdued amid weaker results at the enhanced liquidity auction for longer-dated bonds.

US tariffs of 25% on additional USD 16bln of Chinese goods took effect. There were also comments from China Commerce Ministry that it resolutely opposes the latest US tariffs and will file a complaint to WTO, while Mofcom added it will continue to fight back against US. (Newswires)

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 40bln. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8367 (Prev. 6.8271)
 

UK/EU

UK Brexit Secretary Raab is reportedly to say that EU is being irresponsible regarding the Brexit but is to also state he remains confident a good deal is within horizon. (Newswires/Times)

UK government reportedly plans to impose duties on imports from EU in the event of a no-deal Brexit. (Telegraph)

Brexiteer Jacob Rees-Mogg has written a letter with a point-by-point rebuttal of UK PM May’s Chequers compromise, describing it as “the wrong deal for Britain”, the letter is being sent to Conservative Associations across the country. (Telegraph)

German Chancellor Merkel has reportedly set her sights on backing a German head for the European Commission rather than backing Weidmann for head of the post-Draghi ECB. (Handelsblatt)

FX

In FX markets, the DXY whipsawed and briefly fell below 95.00 in a knee-jerk reaction to the trade-wary FOMC minutes, but then recovered as the statements did little to change the outlook for the Fed’s tightening path as many members viewed it would soon likely be appropriate to raise rates. AUD/USD was the worst performer amongst the major pairs and slipped below the 0.7300 handle amid the leadership crisis in Australia with parliament now suspended until September 10th, while Australian Treasurer Morrison and former Minister for Home Affairs Dutton were touted as leadership candidates to replace PM Turnbull who will not contend if a vote is called. This added fuel to the USD-comeback which coincided with EUR/USD retreating further away from 1.1600 and GBP/USD relinquishing the 1.2900 handle, while commodity-linked currencies also gave back yesterday’s oil-driven gains. Elsewhere, the PBoC set a weaker fix and ZAR was pressured on US scrutiny of South Africa’s farm and land seizures, which all contributed to the tailwinds overnight for the greenback.

Former Australian Home Affairs Minister Dutton requested a 2nd party room meeting which was turned down by PM Turnbull, while Dutton also reportedly told Turnbull majority of the party doesn't support his leadership. Following this, 3 cabinet ministers submitted resignations including Finance Minister Cormann who advised the PM he does not have party support and that there should be a party room meeting to resolve leadership. Australian PM Turnbull later provided a press conference and stated he is waiting for the petition with signatures of majority of party and once received will call for party meeting, while he added will not stand if the party seeks a vote. (Newswires)

US President Trump stated he has asked Secretary of State Pompeo to closely examine the South Africa land and farm seizures, as well as expropriations and large scale killing of farmers. (Twitter)
 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed overnight with WTI crude futures flat as prices took a breather from yesterday’s gains of over 3% which was fuelled by the larger than expected draws in the latest API and DoE inventory reports. Elsewhere, the metals complex declined with gold pressured by a resurgence of the greenback and with copper dragged lower by the predominantly risk-averse tone.

There were initial reports that Saudi Arabia is said to have called-off Saudi Aramco IPO and has disbanded advisors according to sources. However, Saudi Energy Minister Al Falih later denied reports Aramco IPO will be called off. (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICAL

Turkish President Erdogan spokesman stated there is rule of law in Turkey and the case regarding Pastor Brunson is an ongoing legal issue, while the spokesman also stated Turkey has no intention of beginning an economic war but cannot stay silent. (Newswires)
 

US

US Commerce Secretary Ross said now is a good time for a trade spat because of the booming economy and that it will take time to resolve the trade imbalances. Ross also stated there could be retaliation from China on tariffs and that there is some hope anytime there is interaction with China. Furthermore, Ross added there is no deal with Mexico yet, but one is within reach and they hope to get a deal done with Mexico soon. (Newswires)

Mexico Incoming Trade Negotiator Seade said they still working on aspects of rules of origin and was doubtful when asked if there would be an announcement on NAFTA on Thursday but was said to be optimistic that they are coming to an end on NAFTA process. (Newswires)

Canada’s Foreign Minister Freeland said she is very encouraged by the progress in NAFTA talks and is hearing optimism from the US & Mexico, while she also hopes to rejoin talks once US & Mexico issues have been resolved. (Newswires)
